number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I should sue everyone involved with the making of this game. Allowing it to be sold for a measly $5 is simply villainous, my friends. Don't let my Steam playtime deceive you, this game gave me many hours of enjoyment while unable to connect to the mmo's I typically play due to no internet. In times of such darkness, I turn to Dungeons of Dredmor. Below I will explain this game's pure awesomeness.Pros+ Large amount of skills, each varying, humorous and genuinely useful. You choose seven skills to use at the start of the game, then choose which you invest in which essentially allows you to create your own class with its own skill-trees+ Fitting artstyle and music+ Hilarious, un-matched humor that is always refreshing and never (seriously), never gets old. SKOL! LUTEFISK FOR THE LUTEFISK GOD!! Also that noise the diggle makes when it comes up out of the ground. Sort of a "doodoodaDUUU!" that's so damn cute :3+ Randomly generated dungeon every time with just enough pre-made rooms and events to keep things interesting + ^ that and the numerous skills give this game an absurd amount of replay value that goes well beyond an investment of 5 bucks +Very moddable, with tons of great mods already available on the workshopCons- I don't know, you're part of the Diggle Rights Movement? No real cons, honestly, and for 5 bucks who caresNow that we've got that out of the way, let's talk expansions. Each of the expansions add more skills, all of which are hilarious, not to mention some of the funnest in the game (Communism skill seriously rocks) and are both totally worth 3 bucks if you dig the game as much as I do. Also, free expansion? Say what!? (I named mine March of the Diggles, by the way)  In all, if you like roguelikes, buy this game. Actually, if you like games in general just buy it. It's five bucks and I've probably got more enjoyment out of this little indie title than I did in Skyrim.TL;DR VERSION: Infinite hours of fun for five dollars. 10/10 Krong Anvils.

Posted: June 18, 2016
												This game is definitely something you can sink alot of time into. Being able to customize your character with a mix of different skills every run brings in alot of combinations, and adds to the replayability value of the game. the game uses a very odd, yet satisfying sense of humor, and alot of references can be found throughout the game as well. There is no real story to follow, but that's pretty common for roguelikes. I will say it can feel slightly repetitive, especially once you find a set of skills that work well together or you feel you suits your play style. It's only $5, so I don't see any reason not to buy it. I was definitely hesitant to buy this just after looking at the screenshots, but I have no regrets now.Definitely recommended to anyone who enjoys roguelikes.Beware Diggle Hell, and be prepared to press space bar alot. (I would also recommend Tales of Maj'Eyal to anyone who has already played through Dungeons of Dredmor. TOME is like a much more hardcore and in-depth version of Dredmor with even lower graphics quality. Fair warning though, you may not like it as much as Dredmor.)

content:
Posted: April 10
												Soooo... Dungeons of Dredmor. This game is a rogue-like (one of my favorite genres) so it's different from games like The Binding of Isaac, FTL (Rogue-lite) and it has most of his gameplay features present in the 1980 game Rogue like turn-based combat, randomized levels on a level structure and permadeath (you can disable it). But the game adds many more features like the possibility to personalize the character with different skill trees instead of a classic class system.The graphics are good but after a while it may bore the eyes but it's still better than ASCII graphics.The music is meh, some tracks are good like the tutorial one but the others sounds like the cat of the composer got on the keyboard and started jamming the keys.Overall the game is one of the best rogue-like that i've played even with all the little defects and i love it and the workshop adds that cherry on the top of the cakeFinal Vote 8/10P.S. Someone complains that the game crashes often with the autosave feature, it never happened to me but remember to save often.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												If you haven't gotten this game already, then why the hell not?! This game is cheap, insanely replayable and just pure fun. Fans of dungeon crawlers such as FATE will love this (I know I do.) With a wide variety of skills, weaponry and armour complete with random and amusing names that are randomly generated, Dungeons of Dredmor is an amazing turn-based RPG game and I defy anyone to not enjoy this game for at least a few hours. It also has steam workshop, so if you get bored of the "vanilla" aspects of the game you can subcribe to a multitude of equally as amazing mods that make you want to go back to the game over and over again. BUY IT NOW.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												I can't remember when I bought this, but I got the Diggle Nog cheevo for the 2011 Winter Sale event, so that could say something.  It took about three years of hiatus and 107 hours to finally kill Dredmor...once.  On Easy (and Permadeath).Dredmor is a roguelike, and I think it's a pretty good introduction to the genre since I've not really played many of them.  You start out by picking from three difficulties, if you want your character to be permanently deleted when he/she dies or not, and if you bought the Realm of the Diggle Gods expansion, if you want to have 10 or 15 floors.  From there, you're given a page full of skills and you're to pick seven to make your character build, as opposed to having set classes like Warrior or Battlemage or whatnot--or you can just pick Random and see how that does.  And then you're given your choice of cosmetic gender, you name your character, and you're sent on your merry way.Everything is laid out on a grid and every time you move or attack uses up a turn, where everything else is allowed to move or attack.  You can quite literally stand with enemies surrounding you and nothing will happen until you do something.  You level up with enough EXP by killing enemies, destroying Dredmor statues, or unlocking doors/chests with lockpicks.  When you level up, you recover all HP/MP, and you're given your choice of your seven skills to raise which will influence how your stats increase.  Skills work on a linear tree system, but you're allowed to raise your skills in any order, between raising them all up evenly or maxing one as soon as possible.  Every skill in every tree does something, be it simply raising your stats by a set amount or giving you interesting new spells or moves or powers.Combat is pretty much "hit it until it dies" if you're going melee, but every character can use crossbows provided they have ammo and wands as long as they have charges, no matter what build you went with.  Some enemies use long-ranged spells too, so it's a matter of using what you have to counter their threat.  Monsters typically don't show up en masse during the game except in Monster Zoos, big rooms where mooks and minibosses pretty much Zerg Rush you.  You don't necessarily have to clear them out, but you get a free item for wiping everything out, and it's a lot of EXP, too.  You also get free items for doing sidequests gained by praying at the Inconsequentia statues scattered through the dungeons.  They're pretty basic quests--kill this enemy/group, retrieve an item, use this item on a special statue, etc.  I think Dredmor is a pretty fair game in terms of difficulty.  If you die, it's almost always your fault.  Died to a trap?  You carelessly marched forward without enough Trap Sight Radius.  Fight an enemy to where the point both of you are near-death and you miss, dying to its attack?  You didn't heal yourself, retreat, try to lead it into traps, etc.  Of course, this game is randomly-generated so you can quite easily end up with a bad draw on items and stuff, but one draw of roguelikes isn't the game giving you the tools needed to win, but winning with the tools you're given.  No one game is unwinnable if you keep your wits about you and don't get complacent.  The expansions...well, expand.  RotDG adds monsters, skills, items, five more floors; YHTNTEP adds more monsters, items, skills; CotW adds even more monsters and skills and items, but also adds new floors apart from the main dungeon on top of a customizable safe zone (though the base game has a basic version of this place).  There are also quite a few mods on Steam and not on Steam that add more of the above and with things like additional room layouts and so on, but some may require some or all of the expansions, so watch for that.  So yeah, TL;DR I would really recommend this game.  If you're new to roguelikes, this is a pretty good place to start.  Easy mode is pretty easy, hard is pretty damned hard, but that all depends on how the RNG treats you and how you build your characters.  There are a lot of achievements here...though a lot of them require you to die to various critters.  But you know what they say:  Dying is fun!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												Dungeons of Dredmor is a rogue-like dungeon crawler. On first glance, it seems pretty basic and generic as there are so many games with the same genre. However, Dungeons of Dredmor manages to stand out from the rest with it's wide array of skills, items, floors and monsters, it's humor, and how much fun you have playing it. Dungeons of Dredmor has you as a hero to defeat Dark Lord Dredmor. On you quest to defeat Dredmor, you will need weapons, armor and a brain to slaughter monsters across the 10 dungeon floors. DoD has you start off with you picking from about 30 skills (Excluding Deadshot which was removed) and you have the freedom to choose whatever you like. It's a great sense of replayability that is added this way. You can mix and match different skills to see what you like as a player and various skills change your playstyle.. If you happen to mix to certain skills together, you may come up with an amazing combination to destroy some enemies. When you've picked your skills, you get spawned on the first floor. It's good to note that every floor is randomly generated and that the game is turn-based, allowing you to strategize your next move.Now as you progress through the game, different items will be there to enhance your character through different stats, I won't go into detail though. While the same items do pop up on occasion, they feel different because the stats and it's name is always different. Killing enemies will give you XP and will eventually get you to LVL up, therefore giving you one skill point to give you a passive or active skill. As I've said before, the game's large variety increases how much you play. DoD also has a surprising in-depth crafting system that will let you make better weapons, armor and various items like food and potions. DoD also has DLC, which is a must buy. It only enhances the game that's already worth your money.The DLC's add more skills, items, floors and balances the game in general. There is also a decent sized workshop community, constantly added mods to make the game better. Overall, Dungeons of Dredmor is an amazing buy. It's challenging with the option of Permadeath and it really makes you think in a lot of situations. For anyone who loves rouge-likes, you must check this game out. PROS:+Fun and Addicting+Charming+Humorous+Wide Array of Skills+Hundreds of Items+Challenging+Excellent Soundtrack+Permadeath Option+Deep Crafting System+DLC enhances and balances the Base Game+100+ Achievements+Steam Workshop+Bang for Your BuckCONS:-Graphical Style may not be your taste (Grew on me) -Other players have been known to lose their progress-Items don't change character appearance.DUNGEONS OF DREDMOR: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: November 27, 2011
												Roguelikes too daunting for you? Can't remember if you drink potions by hitting "P" for potion or "Q" for quaff potion? Introducing Dungeons of Dredmor with its revolutionary gameplay system: Having actual graphics!Jokes aside, Dredmor is addictively clever and humorous. Half the fun is blazing your way through the dungeons to see how far you can get; the other half is learning intricasies such as: "just because you have the option to drink something does not mean you should" or "A bolt of mass destruction does exactly what you would hope it would do".

												Goofy and loads of fun. I haven't gotten terribly far yet as I'm not very good but I am not quitting until I beat it at least once! This game does not take itself seriously so if you're looking for a rogue with a somber atmosphere this isn't it.If you're looking for a game that rewards you with taunts for your mistakes (playfully) and has achievements for just about every misstep you can make so you can look back fondly on all your ill-advised choices, this is it.I don't usually like these kinds of games as I find them too obtuse for my enjoyment but this one has something special about it.Maybe it's the massive eyebrows.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Missing alot of strategy elements and decisions. Very simplified. If feels like the Munchkin version  of what was supposed to be a roguelike. There is a difference between random for the sake of random and an engine designed to be random but with plenty of modifiers and things that affect outcomes and many solutions for every problem. When you die rarely is it because of an element of the game that you didnt understand properly or something that could have been stopped or modified if you had taken the proper steps to prevent it. If you want a good true roguelike from the steam store buy Tales of Maj'eyal or Vulture for nethack(nethack is free so are most of the tile sets, but vulture has a GUI and mouse controls so its easier to play without having to remember the 40-60 commands for nethack). The Nethack engine is by far the most in depth classic roguelike engine on steam even though its over 20 years old. Or get Wazhack for a different style of rogue

Posted: January 14, 2013
												As a fan of the old Rouge-alike games years ago, I find Dungeons of Dredmore to have a familiar 'feel' about it. The sheer amount of items, and crafting ability you have makes the game entertaining on its own. Add to that the random skill generation (you can choose these specifically too) and what you have is a thoroughly addictive game that almost anyone would enjoy! It takes a couple hours to get used too, but its so worth it :)

Posted: September 19, 2014
												This game serves as an excellent example of how something can be "dinky" and still good. There are all sorts of "rogue-like" and "rogue-lite" games on Steam nowadays, and this is certainly among the best.You're basically a person with some customized build of your choosing going through a dungeon with the goal of becoming more powerful and slaying some guy. The story is comical and background noise at best, and the real strength of the game is in exploration and advancement.The one flaw in this game is the art style. Obviously, the graphics are very low tech, but there is a difference between "good" low tech (Shovel knight, Braid, etc) and "bad" low tech, and this, albeit barely, falls into the bad. Everything around you kinda looks vomit-colored and some of the monsters blend in with the scenery so well that they look like furniture. If it weren't for the fact that items "sparkled" when on the ground, you'd really have no way of knowing the difference between a new pair of boots and a corpse. Dob't get me wrong; it's not the worst looking game in the world by any means, but it could easily be made better.In short, this game is cheap and goes on sale a fair bit. It's perfectly for when you've got some spare time at work and things are slow, so you should look to add it to your library when you get the chance.

content:
Posted: January 19
												When my friends told me I needed to go kill a dark lord, I thought it was the shrooms talking. Turns out it wasn't. I woke up in a dungeon, the way out was locked, and there are drill-faced hell penguins everywhere. And mushrooms, all over the place.Mushrooms? I got this.By the time I hit the 15th floor, Lord Dredmor is waiting for me. Me? I'm high as a kite, tripping puffballs, I've got spores coming out of my pores, swinging swords and lips drenched with blood. Some crazy bottle of hooch I found back on the 7th floor brought me into harmony with the stars, man, so I'm stellar. I look into Dredmor's dead eyes and stuff a handful of shrooms into my face.Coward knows he's in over his head, and teleports away. Aw, hell.I blast my way through the entire bottom floor, a fungal lady of death, killing everything that moves, but the jerk isn't there. What the hell, Dredmor? How rude is it to hide from your guests? I grind up some shrooms and rub the powder in my eyes and realize, damn, these walls are hollow. One Bolt of Mass Destruction flushes Dredmor out, he's not casting cause I revoked his license, he's running cause the shroom girl is screaming, he's stuck, he's got a Holy Hand Grenade on his face, boom.And the diggles said my degree in dungeoneering means nothing here. Hah.

Posted: September 19, 2014
												This game serves as an excellent example of how something can be "dinky" and still good. There are all sorts of "rogue-like" and "rogue-lite" games on Steam nowadays, and this is certainly among the best.You're basically a person with some customized build of your choosing going through a dungeon with the goal of becoming more powerful and slaying some guy. The story is comical and background noise at best, and the real strength of the game is in exploration and advancement.The one flaw in this game is the art style. Obviously, the graphics are very low tech, but there is a difference between "good" low tech (Shovel knight, Braid, etc) and "bad" low tech, and this, albeit barely, falls into the bad. Everything around you kinda looks vomit-colored and some of the monsters blend in with the scenery so well that they look like furniture. If it weren't for the fact that items "sparkled" when on the ground, you'd really have no way of knowing the difference between a new pair of boots and a corpse. Dob't get me wrong; it's not the worst looking game in the world by any means, but it could easily be made better.In short, this game is cheap and goes on sale a fair bit. It's perfectly for when you've got some spare time at work and things are slow, so you should look to add it to your library when you get the chance.

Posted: September 14, 2011
												A fun modern roguelike with a great sense of humor. Besides being turn-based with traps and randomization this isn't your typical roguelike; archaic design is thrown out the window and gameplay is intuitive and can be mouse or keyboard driven. There is no hunger or limited turns and permanent death is completely optional across the three difficulty settings. There are tons of skill builds to choose from and most of them are fun and useful in some way or another. Graphics are nothing special but it does look good for a roguelike and there is enough variation between floors to keep things fresh. The soundtrack is surprisingly good and this game is worth about twice what it costs, so buy it if you like the genre. Exceptional replay value.

Posted: July 15, 2014
												Though a pretty cool game I did NOT have a great personal experience with it.A LOT of skills, crafting options, and equipment within the dungeon to choose from.All skills are chosen from the very beginning and are upgradeable as you level up in the game. They range from highly practical to just downright ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles (though still useful).A lot of the fancy crafting has to be done with specific crafting skills that you have to choose when you start the game. They can range from armor, weapons, crossbow bolts, more crafting materials, potions, etc. Every type of item category in the game has a lot of items under them. The fancier stuff either have to be crafted or, if you're lucky, just found randomly as you explore.Loot can be far too plentiful and since I usually like to hoarde loot I was easily overwhelmed by how much I had to let go and sell off to make room. If you're a bit lucky you can get a storage-like item in the form of a big room where you can put a load of crap in and access it whenever & wherever you want.The whole game can be rather difficult if you just rush through it so you're sort of forced to keep killing enemies and exploring to find and/or make better equipment.Along with the cool stuff here I've also got a few personal problems with this game and one of them is how lenghty these dungeons can be. I like to explore every nook and cranny of a dungeon usually and these maps can be huge. There are 10 levels in this dungeon (15 if you have that DLC). Exploring can be delayed by way of a huge mob of enemies coming at me, kicking my♥♥♥♥♥♥ and forcing me to reload to my last save thus having me think of better ways to get through said obstacles.Another problem I have is that I crash every now and again when, I presume, it attemps to auto-save which I can't toggle on or off. Luckily there's a manual save but there's no real way to load a file while you're in the dungeon. If you want to quit the game you're either forced to save & quit, crash, or end the process via task manager. You can only make ONE file per playthrough too meaning you can't choose another slot for another save in one run; you only have your manual save file and your auto-save file.This probably won't happen to everyone but the one thing that ticked me off the most is that after 30+ hours of playing this game I get to the final Level, run into the boss of this whole game (Lord Dredmor) and suddenly have him disappear thus leaving me with no way to finish the game. While fighting him he teleports every now and again just to mess with you and throw magic at you but for MY case he teleports and just vanishes. I've explored the whole dungeon multiple times to see if he's just messing with me again but he was nowhere to be found thus labeling my over-two-dozen-hour playthrough to be a waste. It was guaranteed a waste because my only saves took place after he bugged out since I thought he was just somewhere in the current level waiting for me.Overall, it's still a great game (and at a cheap price, too) with a lot of exploring & crafting, equipment, and skill options to choose from. Also don't let the not-so-stellar artwork be a downer.

Posted: July 19, 2011
												A must if you've played any traditional roguelikes, though it's arguably not as difficult (still comes with multiple difficulties and a togglable permadeath, at least). With a unique stats system and starting skills that can be combined in creative ways, Dungeons of Dredmor delivers a humorous, addictive, and highly replayable dungeon crawler. There are also plenty of items to discover, including potions and mushrooms that each bear different effects upon the user, as well as an array of weapons and armor with silly damage types and resistances (e.g. a ring that provides existential damage resistance to its user, or a dagger that deals asphyxiating and aethereal damage to its target).Sometimes the best way to get into a roguelike is to dive in without any prior research, and at its price, Dungeons of Dredmor is a steal.

												A lot of us define a good game by one we can sink a "£1 an hour of good gameplay", and in that sense, Dungeons of Dredmor is one of the best investments possible - you can get it, with all the DLC, for only £5. I've currently got 51 hours in it, so it's been more than a good investment, in that sense.The gameplay is... Solid. It's turn based, so  you're hardly on the edge of your seat, but the enemies are unique and the taunts are funny. Lots of references. There's even a fantastic mod, "Death by One Thousand Taunts", which adds even more. It's great.Because there's a surprising amount of workshop content for a near-six year old game, some mods add new skill trees, etc., so even if you do a playthrough of every skill type, there'll be new ones to try.I never thought I could play rogue-likes. I'm not that great at Binding of Isaac, though that might be because you cannot save and exit it, however with Dredmor, you can save and exit, so you can come back and replay whenever you want.You can run this in a potato. And get more than enough hours into it to make it more than worth the while. 9/10 a fantastic investment.

Posted: July 18, 2014
												I got an achievment for the game crashing. 10/10In all seriousness, though, this game is fantastic. It has incredibly fluid gameplay, which is both challenging and addictive. The combat is a little like Skyrim, in that you can get out of it exactly what you want. I'm generally kind of cheap, but there is no question about this game being worth its asking price. My suggestion is that you get the DLCs as well. They're cheap and they add a ton of content to an already fantastic game. Plus, you get the full range of mods from this game's wonderful community.If I had to pick a gripe, however, it would be an aesthetic one. I don't love the way the game looks, though it is serviceable. The main character's eyebrows are almost distractingly large. Aside from that, none of the equipment that you pick up or craft shows up your character. This is a little irritating, as it doesn't necessarily give you the sense of progression that one might want out of a game like this. Regardless, however, this game is fantastic. If you're into dungeon crawlers or rogulelikes, don't even hesitate to pick this one up. It's a real gem.

Posted: August 18, 2014
												A silly, beginner-friendly yet potentially tough roguelike.To me, its greatest strength is the customization - you can pick seven skill paths for each character, which heavily influence gameplay and can result in interesting combinations. Additionally, there's user-created skills and other content, some of which is as clever and balanced as the original game.Compared to NetHack and most similar roguelikes,  there's a lot more focus on clarity, but there's still some things you have to learn through experimentation. There's also a lot more focus on spellcasting and character creation and the (optional) crafting system.Combat is fairly hack-and-slay, which can feel pretty tedious, but there's a "no time to grind" option for smaller floors, and synergetic abilities can finish battles a lot faster.The game features three difficulty modes and the option to turn off permadeath, so beginners (and anyone else) can reduce its frustration potential if they want to. On the other hand, the hardest difficulty delivers a great challenge akin to traditional roguelikes.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												Gaslamp Game’s first production, Dungeons of Dredmor, has accumulated quiet a cult following since its release two years ago, combining the unpredictability of rougelikes with the slick, mobile ready interface younger gamers have come to expect. But the fundamental issue with for-profit rougelikes are two-fold: they are directly challenging some of the greatest games ever made, and two, all of their competition is free. I will put my cards on the table. I am a diehard Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup fan. I play it on my phone when I’m waiting in line. I squeeze a quick game in before bed most nights. The depth, years of production, and meticulous balance are difficult to find outside of the RL genre. And, it’s absolutely, positively, 100% free. So when the competitor’s game starts off costing infinitely more than nothing, it’s already at a disadvantage. This is compounded by DoD’s other glaring flaw which is balance, or lack thereof. It is clear that the game was built, from concept to code to graphics, as a lark. Everything is a joke. All the references make it a blast to play. There are enough jokes that it even adds to replayability. But it also killed any shred of equality the game once had. Instead of picking a class and a race, as is standard with most RPGs, you pick seven skill trees which effect both passive stats and activated abilities, and go on your merry way. But pick the wrong trees, or wrong combination of trees, and you will find progression past a certain point impossible. For example, I would love to use the pole arm class. But the scarcity of the weapon itself, along with the subpar nature of the skill tree, makes it useless when compared to the sword or mace or even unarmed skills. About a fifth of the skill trees involve crafting, which in all cases is satisfactorily powerful, but turns the game from a fast paced dungeon romp into a painfully accurate hoarding simulation. Jokes about polishing your wand are great, I just wish the wand crafting skill was as much fun to use as it was to read about.But in light of all this. In spite of the cost, regardless of the glaring flaws in the mechanics, I have still spent time playing this game, and avidly suggest it to friends who aren’t ready for a full on ASCII rougelike experience. It’s a fantastic gateway to a genre otherwise regarded as impenetrable. My issues arise from playing games like it for years, but for someone who doesn’t enjoy their eyes bleeding, a few extra dollars and inept skill trees will not sullen the experience. The controls are straight forward and predictable. And the experience is still that of a rouge like. All the frustration and theory crafting in a nice, accessible package. You will love this game. You will hate this game. But most importantly, you will play this game. You won’t spend all your time in menus figuring out how to quaff a potion, or figuring out what a certain object is. You will spend your time dying, and that’s what rougelikes are all about.So if you’re looking for a new experience, and have no idea what a NetHack is or think Dwarf Fortress is a chapter out of Lord of the Rings, there is no better place to start than with Dungeons of Dredmor. If, like me, you have past experience with the genre, you may find the depth a bit lacking. But overall, I applaud the developers efforts to make a deserving medium accessible.

Luckily there's a manual save but there's no real way to load a file while you're in the dungeon. If you want to quit the game you're either forced to save & quit, crash, or end the process via task manager. You can only make ONE file per playthrough too meaning you can't choose another slot for another save in one run; you only have your manual save file and your auto-save file.This probably won't happen to everyone but the one thing that ticked me off the most is that after 30+ hours of playing this game I get to the final Level, run into the boss of this whole game (Lord Dredmor) and suddenly have him disappear thus leaving me with no way to finish the game. While fighting him he teleports every now and again just to mess with you and throw magic at you but for MY case he teleports and just vanishes. I've explored the whole dungeon multiple times to see if he's just messing with me again but he was nowhere to be found thus labeling my over-two-dozen-hour playthrough to be a waste. It was guaranteed a waste because my only saves took place after he bugged out since I thought he was just somewhere in the current level waiting for me.Overall, it's still a great game (and at a cheap price, too) with a lot of exploring & crafting, equipment, and skill options to choose from. Also don't let the not-so-stellar artwork be a downer.

Posted: July 19, 2011
												A must if you've played any traditional roguelikes, though it's arguably not as difficult (still comes with multiple difficulties and a togglable permadeath, at least). With a unique stats system and starting skills that can be combined in creative ways, Dungeons of Dredmor delivers a humorous, addictive, and highly replayable dungeon crawler. There are also plenty of items to discover, including potions and mushrooms that each bear different effects upon the user, as well as an array of weapons and armor with silly damage types and resistances (e.g. a ring that provides existential damage resistance to its user, or a dagger that deals asphyxiating and aethereal damage to its target).Sometimes the best way to get into a roguelike is to dive in without any prior research, and at its price, Dungeons of Dredmor is a steal.

Posted: September 14, 2011
												A fun modern roguelike with a great sense of humor. Besides being turn-based with traps and randomization this isn't your typical roguelike; archaic design is thrown out the window and gameplay is intuitive and can be mouse or keyboard driven. There is no hunger or limited turns and permanent death is completely optional across the three difficulty settings. There are tons of skill builds to choose from and most of them are fun and useful in some way or another. Graphics are nothing special but it does look good for a roguelike and there is enough variation between floors to keep things fresh. The soundtrack is surprisingly good and this game is worth about twice what it costs, so buy it if you like the genre. Exceptional replay value.

Posted: January 25, 2014
												Robust yet simple, deep yet entirely lighthearted, Dungeons of Dredmor is a shining example of a roguelike done in exactly the right way-- Hilariously.This is how it's meant to be. You build a unique character from skill pools ranging from simple swordsmanship and spellcraft to things like math, legal, and veganism-based combat, and proceed through a randomized, turn-based dungeon in the traditional roguelike style- which is to say, slowly, with an emphasis on choosing what you'll do next and contending with the consequences. Commands are never overwhelmingly complicated, with the game dishing out new active skills conservatively, and yet there never seems to be a shortage of ways to handle any given situation. As frequently as death comes (it's the nearest thing to an inevitability), there's always the sense that maybe, just maybe it would have been better to hurl something at that last monster and run away than to have tried to sneak up on it. While there's inevitably some frustration in trekking through a dungeon for a full hour before being reduced to a bloody, lifeless high score, Dredmor eases the pain with variable difficulties and and the option of turning off the permadeath, so impatient adventurers might throw themselves into something brutish and horrible just to get the full experience before rounding out their experience with a swift death, while more anxious players might tone down the experience to something more casual and preserve their precious adventurer until the game's proper end. The sheer extent to which your uniquely-tailored character can actually be developed keeps the latter approach from getting stale too quickly, while the extent to which your handpicked skill trees actually matter from the beginning keeps the quick and dirty approach fresh from restart to restart.In the end, if there's a single thing working against Dredmor's lovingly-crafted delves, it's the entire genre's problem: Every move is its own intimate life-or-death decision, with all the time in the world to choose between as many actions as your character is capable of, and as such it can only have ever been a single-player experience. As tempting as it is to tell your friends about that incredible time you narrowly escaped a desperate one-sided fight by electing to abandon your sword and instead physically throw the monster into a brutal trap, it's an experience you'll have invariably shared with yourself alone. It simply can't be helped- Dungeons of Dredmor is a very single-player game, and yet it still does its best to keep you company. Each learned skill rarely comes without a joke to accompany it, monsters sling petty insults your way, and even in your most dramatic victories, the game's narration will do everything in its power to take the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you- but what more can you expect when you're a law-school educated burglar, communist viking, or Regent of Throwing Stuff At People? Dredmor's a lonely experience, but makes every effort not to feel like one.Overall, if you've ever been a fan of roguelikes, Dungeons of Dredmor is a refreshingly unique presentation of everything you're already certain you like, and if you've never touched one before, Dredmor is still a perfectly complete example of everything the genre ought to be, with success dependent on what you do, rather than how fast you can do it. As hard as you make it, as deep as you feel like going, and dripping with wit and charm (and other fluids), this game isn't content to simply kill you repeatedly. It wants to be your friend while it does so.My advice? Let it. Unless you've specifically got a problem with turn-based or single-player gaming, Dungeons of Dredmor is a humble yet delightful dungeon-crawl worth far more than its modest price tag in delicious suspense, strategy, humor, and gratuitous fantasy violence.

Posted: February 21, 2012
												DoD is a really fun "roguelike" RPG. While the story has no depth, and the presentation of the graphics and sound are extremely basic, the character creation system is varied, and the turn based combat is very tactical. Each character selects 7 skills from a pool of 30+, which cover melee and ranged combat, offensive magic, summons, buffs, crafting, thieving, and more. Each skill can be improved at level up to unlock new spells or abilities. The strategy of combat revolves around knowing where to position yourself, and choosing the right time to use an ability, item or spell. The many different combinations of skills provides lots of varied playing styles. Replayability is further extended by each of the 10+ dungeon floors having a random layout for every new game. The ultimate challenge is to play through in permadeath mode, where your character and any saves are deleted upon death. The low purchase price is ridiculously good value for money.

												I found Dungeons of Dredmor somewhat compelling, but every time I would play, I would get sucked in for several hours as I traipsed through level after level systematically destroying everything, only to get wiped out by one stupid play. I eventually decided I was wasting too much time with it and not enjoying it any more, so I uninstalled it. I found it frustrating that I couldn't min-max *everything* because some crafting recipes are pretty much always not available to you. I liked the skill system and that you can choose several rather than just rolling up one of seven different classes or whatever, and some of the descriptions were entertaining, but ultimately my problem with roguelikes is that they often end up as the video game equivalent of road hypnosis -- you spend hours and hours playing them and then you slip up once and you're toast. Or maybe I'm just playing them wrong?

												Dungeons of Dredmor is one of my favorite games.  It is just so much fun to play, so many small little thing have been refined to just make it a really fun and good game. It has a lot of skills you can choose from, the crafting is pretty large and it really gives you a lot of options on how to play it. If you think the game is a bit of a grind you can turn on "no time to grind." It speeds up the game quite a bit.  If you think it is too hard you can try easy. If you think the game isn't forgiving enough you can turn off permadeath. The humor is great, and the interface is really well done, making the game feel very fun to play. nowadays I usually play on no time to grind, 15 floors normal difficulty with random skills, there are still skills I haven't played a full game with, plus there is a lot of community stuff as well so it almost feels like it is endless fun. Posted: October 14, 2014
												What can I say about Dungeons of Dredmor? Well, first of all, let me say that this is the first time I've played a roguelike and enjoyed it. Immensely. This is perhaps the most accessible, most enjoyable roguelike game out there, with a great artstyle, a metric butt-ton of nerdy jokes and references to things like Doctor Who, Discworld, etc, and some of the most hilarious achievement sets I've seen thus far on Steam (there is literally an achievement for kicking a door until you die from a broken foot). This game has almost infinite replayability, with dozens of skills in nearly endless combinations and enough mods out there to keep the game going long after you've played the whole shebang, Dredmor is a delightful, near-endless experience I'd recommend to anyone with a bit of extra cash on their hands.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Dungeons of Dreamor is a dungeon crawling RPG with an interesting take on the turn based approach. By that, I mean that your actions count as turns. You don't go into a battle mode, the entire game works on turns. If you take a step, pick up an item, use an item, use a spell, use an attack, defend... all of these things count as a turn. So whenever you do something, every enemy gets to as well. This is also used in coodowns on abilities and regeneration of health and magic. Insead of waiting on a timer, you do actions to keep the game moving. It's great for pacing. Before you even start playing, you have some options you can set, and then you get to pick from a number of different abilities. So you're not restricted to a class, as in some other games like this. Instead, you just pick whatever abilities you want, which is fun for customization and replayability. As you level up, you can chose to level up those abilities as you see fit, but only one per level. The gameplay, aside from the turn system, is pretty standard. You walk around a huge dungeon, fighting enemies and looting the place. You can also craft a great number of things along the way, provided you have the materials, the tool used to craft it, and enough points in the required skill to make the item. This is where I start to have some issues.See, you can pick your own skills. You can also level your own skills as you please. But sometimes you'll pick skills that don't cover the areas you need in order to make certain items. If you don't have that to level up, you simply cannot make those types of items. That can be annoying. It can also be annoying to have all the materials, the skills, and not the tool required to make the item. Although that can be remedied by finding one somewhere in the dungeon. My biggest complaint is that the inventory you have is a tad small. It makes you have to manage your items well, constantly craft items to use up materials (but that's not always so easy to do), or constantly backtrack to the shops to sell things. I guess you could leave stuff laying around but then it'd go to waste. Having a few more slots would help a lot. I guess it comes with the territory of looting. And with the skill complain, I suppose you just have to plan ahead and know what you can and can't do, which in turn will help you identify which items you do and do not need. Some of the skills in the begining don't explain what they do, choosing to have a joke description instead. This can be annoying to deal with and try to remember what they actually do later. Some of the drinkable and edible items you get aren't specific about what they do either. You might drink something or eat something that puts a debuff on you, hurts you, or even kills you! And the game is littered with traps. Some you can see, some you can't. Sometimes you can go around them, sometimes you need to walk over them to get to another spot. Sometimes you can disable them, sometimes that'll fail and they'll go off anyways. Imagine hitting a random trap that you couldn't even see, only to have THAT be the end of all your hard work. With permadeath on (as the default), it's quite maddening. Still, this game is massive and... very difficult. I've sunk almost 20 hours into it as of right now and and never made it past the second floor. Am I bad? Maybe. But it's pretty easy to die from random stuff. I may have misread this but I think there's something like ten floors normally and fifteen with the expansions. So there's tons of stuff to do in this game. There's even tons of things I haven't even figured out yet! It's an amazing amount of content and playtime for what only costs you 5 bucks. Heck, toss in the extra buck for the DLC and get even more out of it like I did. It's very well worth the price tag and I'm really surprised it isn't going for more than that. It could definitely be a 10 or even 15 dollar game. Dungeons of Dreadmor gets an 8/10 for being an immense dungeon crawler with an interesting take at a great price.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												I sat down to play Dredmor one night, and then I realised 248 hours had passed and the sun had come up 10 times... or was it 11?Dredmor is a turn-based procedurally generated dungeon crawler (with the option for permadeath) in which you clear out a dungeon level by level until you hit the bottom and kill the final boss - a pretty simple premise and no back-story to speak of; but that's okay, this game is all about the gameplay, and the loot (oh so much loot).The crafting system is pretty well designed and there's a lot of cool stuff to make (such as chainswords!!) but it's also kind of a pain because it's hard to know what scrap metals and garbage to keep in your limited inventory as you won't have access to all the blueprints at the start of each play-through, and you rely on randomly finding the right ones.Dredmor has all the standard RPG skill trees like swordplay and archery, but it also includes some pretty weird skill trees such as mathemagician, tourist, and communist. The best thing is that, regardless of what seven skills you pick for your character, you are not locked into using certain types of equipment. If you find it, you can use it regardless of class or level. This means you can just play the character any way you want to, which is a lot more fun than being locked into the standard warrior, mage, or thief classes like in many other RPGs.Dredmor includes lots of references to other games and popular culture, and it kind of reminds me of older games that didn't have to be so serious. This really gives the game the extra shot of charm it needs to help you look past it's flaws (and there's a lot of flaws in Dredmor, I just choose to ignore them because it's so much fun).9 out of 10, would grind (and there's a lot of grinding to be done, but it's a good kind of grind).

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Dungeons of Dredmor is a pretty fun look at the old roguelike genre, and was a great romp down memory lane. While the graphics are simple, as is the gameplay, a simple interface masks a surprisingly deep customization and talent system. The synergy between different skills will have you experimenting with builds for DAYS. The addition and seamless integration of Steam Workshop was nothing short of brilliant, and when you feel like you've seen everything in Dungeons of Dredmor, provides HOURS of extra enjoyment.Good: Solid gameplay, fun visual aesthetic, good music. Deep and complex customization presented in a brilliantly accesible way.Bad: Some skills are just too good. Whenever there's a skill that me and ALL my friends separately came to the conclusion that it MUST be in your build, things need a little tinkering. Ugly: Not much.Possibly the worst thing I can say about DoD is that the era of the traditional rogue formula is definitely showing its age. The procedure of "I move, then all enemies move, then I move" is showing its age as a design process. Dungeons of Dredmor could be that last, best look at a wonderful genre, and I enjoyed the hell out of it, but I think it will be the last true rogue I play. It's time to see what the words "rogue like" can do attached to other formats of gameplay.

Didn't think I was going to enjoy this game as much as I do, but it's challenging and addicting. At a certain point, it feels a bit grindy, but there's the option to streamline dungeon size such that your spending less time on each floor but still progressing through the game. Plenty of replay value if you like exploring different play styles and challenging yourself!And there's seriously nothing like strutting around feeling like you own the place and then feeling your stomach drop when you open a door to a monster zoo.Buy this game, it's totally worth the price, and you'll have a blast adventuring!

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												One of the most fun and addictive games I have ever found. Endless dungeon-crawling goodness with an enormous array of skills, tools, and combinations, a great sense of fun, and the ability to progress at your own speed. You can always roll up a new character and find something you hadn't seen before, or learn a new trick. The game is a series of dungeons descending to an ultimate evil, with pocket dimensions, shops, and altars to various gods along the way. You create a character with a wide selection of skills in different trees (Archeology, Paranormal Investigation, Barbarian, to name only a few) which you can then level up as you progress. Along the way you fight strange and often hilarious monsters and collect materials to craft or sell. Strange combinations of these produce interesting results, mixing in teleportation, tunneling, invisibility, mind control, and many more!The game is charming, the art is lovely, the creators are helpful and responsive, and the music is pleasant. Try it.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I have a soft spot for roguelites, even though I'm (generally speaking) absolutely SHÏTE at them. But they're usually a whole lotta fun. Charging into a horde of enemies, battle-axe in hand, loincloth flapping in the wind, and then getting stomped into monster sandwich spread because what kind of a fûckin' retärd doesn't wear PROPER armour when they're out savaging monsters?!But I digress. Dungeons of Dredmor then. I like it. I won't go so far as to say that I love it, but I will just spoil this review right now and tell you: YES, I WILL RECOMMEND THIS FÛCKING SHÏT, BECAUSE IT'S A REALLY GOOD GAME.I feel like I basically cut myself short just now, seeing as how I don't have all THAT much to talk 'bout when it comes to ol' DoD. I mean, the humour in it is nicely silly, without being overly dumb. And I do like that it's not pitching a tent in either the Bulletstorm cesspit or the Duke Nukem Forever leper colony, but the much less unappealing Monty Python-esque silly nonsense, uhh... fish factory. I dunno. I was struggling to come up with something, so I just wrote the first thing that came to mind.Anyway! Moving on. I like that pretty much every single skill in the game is at least somewhat unique, and that they all have some measure of usefulness, even though some are pretty damn overpowered (lookin' at you, Perception (yes, that was a pun, get over it)) while some are... well... less useful (*coughs* veganism *coughs*). But anyway. The ability to mix 'n' match skills 'til your boxers squeal (because the expression "till your hearts contents" makes no göddämn fûcking sense!), so you'll have plenty of replay value.The gameplay itself is nicely straight-forward. You typically walk around with WASD, you see an enemy, approach them, and then either bump up against 'em or click on 'em to attack. Not exactly rocket surgery, ehh? But the fact that the game is, how should I say... "step-based", I guess? Well, whatever you'd call it, it's the only hybridization of real-time and turn-based I've ever seen that actually works really well.Those of you who've played Fatal Labyrinth on the SEGA Genesis know what I mean. To clarify, enemies can only move, attack, and do other stuff at the same time as you do, but you don't take traditional turns attacking each other. So when you attack an enemy, they'll attack you back. This makes it so that you'll ALWAYS have time to think about what to do next, but the pacing of the game doesn't necessarily suffer for it, unlike in games like Heroes of Might & Magic or XCOM.The graphics are fairly simple and low-key, just to change the topic com-fûcking-pletely, but they have a nicely stylistic charm to them. Most pixel games generally just go for the 8-bit style out of sheer laziness, but DoD seems to take the same road as Stardew Valley or Shovel Knight, and instead have a pixelated style with plenty of details and actually nice colour palettes. Which I obviously like.And now I'm reaching dangerously close to the final point regarding DoD: if it's such a solid game, why do I not like it more? Well, I will warn you right now that it's insanely fûcking grindtastic, and unless you play with the Smaller Floors option on, you'll be doing a fûcking retärded amount-a walking around in the game. There's also the fact that even though almost all skills are in some way useful, there are builds that WILL inevitably break the game, even on the hardest difficulty, and basically turn you into an all-powerful mega-god.But I have to admit, DoD does a lotta things really, really, REALLY well, and since my only complaints with it are minor nuisances at most, I really can't give it that low of a grading. It's also worth noting that Dungeons of Dredmor (unlike nearly every single roguelite out there) does actually let you play on a fairly softcore difficulty level, and while I personally wish there were more options to customize the "hardness" of the game, this does make it so that even less skilled players can play it. So that's definitely a big plus.All in all, DoD has a lotta solid points, and while it's a bit rough around the edges, it's still got a lot of charm to it, and it's definitely worth buying, even if you're normally not a huge fan of roguelite games. 8.9/10

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Having played a couple of days and reaching Lord Dredmor, i must conclude that the game:- has a fun set of monsters- invites you to try out new skill combinations, thus has replay value- has a _great_ music- includes lutefiskbut looking back, there are some negative points too:- bugs roughly every 10 minutes (at least on the linux version), ranging from misplaced items (cant reach) or monsters (4 stacked upon), crashes every 30 minutes (after some in-game time / progress)- the crafting system is dysfunctional (getting a lvl1 recipie in the last lvl of the dungeon - too random, too many "silly"/useless crafts, 3 ingots for a simple item without stats - ingots too rare)- fun for 99.9% of the game, then Lord Dredmor kills you with 2 strikes- nonexistent help/tips: "what does potion/mushroom xxx do?" is part of most roguelites, but a simple tooltip how to use knightly leap or what some stat-gain gets you would be very pleasant.- lutefisk cube: The idea is that you can transform every non-food item to lutefisk and then donate it to the fish-god who gives you a random item. But to have a good chance you need about 200 pieces. But trading a 13k gold item for 1 piece of lutefisk?? Would just need some price/lutefisk scaling. This game is in such a nice and interesting state, but lets call it beta quality and finish up those loose ends.

Posted: April 29, 2015
												So... I am writing this review, because the game pushed me towards the edge of negative emotions. Which is quite sad, because the game itself and idea are really good and addictive, sadly not enough to forgive all the non-stop, gamebreaking issues.The mains reasons why I cannot, by any stretch of imagination recommend this game.1. Game crashes. Crashes sometimes are game-breaking, as the game sometimes just does not save at all. A crash couple times after 1-2 hours of playtime led to completely losing the whole progress until that point and resetting everything including game settings, which is impossible to accept,2. Game does not autosave for no apparent reason. It shows during gameplay that game has been saved, yet when starting the game the day after I'm still starting not from what I have left, but from the very previous save, which feels like even bigger waste of time - there is no way I am going to go through same thing I have passed already and got the good stuff and upgraded my character. It's just not fun at all and misses the purpose, because it's far from similar to replaying the game after death. It makes me not want to play it anymore because I don't know when save will work from the proper place and when it won't.3. Numerous glitches, including popping through doors, attacks that were impossible to hit they still do, I believe it's some sort of trying to give an advantage to silly AI which sucks terribly.4. Game performance is just plain awful. It has not been optimized for anything, and as far as the retro visual estetics go, clunkiness and non responsivness to keyboard is one more thing that CAN NOT BE ACCEPTED in game that has been out there for so long.I swear, don't buy it. It's more frustrating than anything you've met and after reading revious others left you can see these are not an uncommon problems. It will make you love the game, and few momens later you will hate it dearly and want your money back so you can get go get a burger instead of buggy, unplayble game. Shame on you, lazy♥♥♥♥♥developer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												This game has been netted as one of my personal favorite roguelikes. A big fan of Gaslamp and their crew - I'm stoked to have been part of a lot of beta testing for the content of this game and even to where an achievement that I suggested on the forums has been added in! :DNow. This game sets up the limits of...weird. And the DLC has only improved it. The crafting system is large and well varied, the Wizard Keys and finding graffitti scrawled on the walls with codes to new levels, all the loot you can shake a stick at, in-game vending machines selling you everything from baseballs to ground meat and nukes and Root Of T'char. The greatest thing about this game is how varied the outcomes can be. You have the choices of 6 different talent trees out of 15+ ones and none are "right" OR "wrong." The game gives you the freedom to play as you please and the Save-Exit function is a godsend when you start delving and you feel tired. Levelling up and playing is turn based and the enemies move as you move.Overall: I have so much fun with this game that I've yet to finish ONE game. 70+ hours on and offline with this game and every time there's that itch to re-roll a character and try a new combination JUST BECAUSE the skill trees augment and vary your gameplay so much!GOOD:-Fair play RPG.-Lots of contents, weapons, combinations, skill trees, items.-So MANY bad/good puns and references to other bits of culture.-Game never really feels 'unfair' or 'hard' as some other roguelikes. There's mostly always a way to live...mostly. Or run away.-Diggles.-Heroic Vandalism!-Do you like eggs? WELL WE GOT A LOT OF 'EM!-SO MANY community mods and addons for this game made by dedicated players. Hate the current skill trees/items? Well replace them!-The monsters yell and insult you whilst you bash their heads in!-Wands, nukes, steampunk, veganism, were-diggle skills, get Wizard-krunked, Astronomy, blacksmithing...gosh!BAD:-The game does have a tendency to be unbalanced at times when it is you happen to delve too quickly and the enemy levels outpace yours and you find yourself getting smacked upside the head.-The same way you can combine types of damages on weapons and armor...remember that the enemy can do it too. Don't be shocked when you get slapped to all hell when you get hit by 4-8 different types at once and get instagibbed with Boss monsters.-The game is rather lengthy and for some players it's a lot to sit through in one sitting. Breaks are nearly mandatory sometimes. Set your number of levels and difficulty in advance.-Do not turn on permaDETH if you're not a fan of dying. Flushing away a couple hours/days work because you got teleported over a body of water and can't swim is enough to make you cry.-Butcher Rooms. Nuff said.-The stability of the game is still questionable at times and prone to some far-spaced but non-lethal bugs. It's a lot to deal with but the game is still stable.PLEASE NOTE that this game is NO LONGER BEING WORKED ON. This is a CLOSED project. Gaslamp has given up nearly all the resources to create the game back to the community to continue making content and debugging and in general have been very, very good to their players. From allowing us to name the expansions, to adding our own achievements, to allowing bug reports in beta they have done so much for this game and honestly...it's a project made with a lot of love.I may be selling you this game wistfully but I guarantee anyone who buys and plays this wonderful project WILL enjoy themselves immensely. I do recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												An excellent game, providing replay value as well as challenge. If you like rogue-like games, this is a good one to invest in. The character choices are many, allowing for any number of gameplay styles and also allowing for an even greater amount of variety, which is fantastic. The skill tree system is straight-forward and nicely balanced, which is lovely as well. It's comedic in many parts, from the absolutely absurd names it randomly generates, to the moderately silly introduction, to the many, many references to a whole bunch of different things - like Morrowind and Bioshock, to name a few. If I had to complain about anything, I'd say that I'd like to see more permanent unlockables, kind of like in The Binding of Isaac, where you can unlock items to find in later runs by achieving certain landmarks.Even at that, however, the game is more than satisfying.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Dungeons of Dredmore is a great rogue-like RPG, playing both as an homage and parody to the hack 'n' slash and roleplaying games of old.  What makes this game stand out most is the artistic style and the humor of the game itself, being sure to take itself just seriously enough to remain a very solid game.  Also worth mention is the music within the game, composed by Matthew Steele.  If you are a lover of the rogue-like genre, this game is a great deal at less than $5 (U.S.)

												It’s a really entertaining rogue-like with a lot of fourth wall breaking humour. The flavour text pokes fun at itself while the game options offer various degrees of difficulty and decent gameplay. Per usual, turn-based style when the enemies act when you act. The UI can be a bit confusing, mainly when it comes to icons on the character sheet – by the end of the game items can have almost a dozen of effects and the icons are small and look similar. Also choosing the “paths” at the beginning is obfuscated by the fact that you’ll see the progression they offer only in game, not at the character creation page. Other than that, a lot fun to play. Score 80%.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Warning, if you've never played this game, minor spoilers ahead. (Like, really minor, but spoilers nonetheless.)This game is a unique combination of simple, easy, difficult, relaxing, laid-back, humorous, and just general old-fashioned fun. Holy crap it's fun. Basically you crawl your way through levels of the dungeon to get to the main bad-guy, accumulating a number of unique and silly items, skills, and badassery. Levelling up always feels good, and gaining a skill almost always has a noticeable affect on your combat.Fair warning, you will die a lot. And if you're like me and love pain, you'll play on perma-death (which is optional). On about my fifth character, I was really getting into the swing of things. I had tons of items. I had a pocket dimension I could go to to dump unwanted detritus that might be useful in the future, and I'd just made it through the second floor (still haven't seen the third; the floors are fairly big and ooze with content and monsters). I was fairly powerful at this point, at least for the floor I was on, and easily laid waste to waves of monsters with the help of my zombies and clouds of poison that I conjured. So, feeling like a badass, I hopped over to my pocket dimension to drop off some loot, when I noticed that from said dimension I could also leap to other dimensions! "Okay, cool," so I did. Plowed through one small dimension, no sweat. So I go to another, run into two monsters, kill myself with my own poison cloud. It was my fault for not paying attention, but alllll the hard work, the several hours I'd put into his skills, levels, items. Gone!At that point I said to myself, "Okay, this is probably the point where going back to the first dungeon just becomes a tedious grind, and I won't want to play anymore." Well tonight I felt like trying again, trying some new skills. Frankly, it's no less fun than when I played for the first time. The floors are all randomly generated, so it's never the same run between characters.My current character has kicks that literally explode into fire, tearing through enemies like nothing, and I'm only on the first floor.It's not just the content, it's the little quirks. You can tell the developers had a blast making this game. Everything shines with creativity and humour, and it's just a lovely little game gah I love it.10/10, recommended a thousand times yes. It's cheap, you should buy it with the expansions. Get ready to lose at least a few hours a day.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												ARGH THIS GAME IS SO GOODIt's a fun little rogue-like (and a genuine rogue-like this time,) where every runthrough is different and fun in its own way. You can try-hard it or mash the random button when choosing your character's skills at start and still have a pretty good time. The game is simple and streamlined where it needs to be and more complex where it should be. Grab the DLC too, and pick up some small mods that don't interfere with the core experience too much, and you've got yourself a fun experience that you won't regret. I'm willing to say this is the best *real* rogue-like (and not just a game with rogue-like elements; Binding of Isaac for example) on Steam.I highly recommend going in on the highest difficulty setting with hardcore mode on.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E28 Dungeons of Dredmor 

			Views: 145		

			Want something that's totally self-aware, makes you worship lute fish gods, do inconsequential quest and gives you quanta tons of content to sift through?		

Dungeons of Dredmor: An old schoolish, dungeon crawling, loot grabbing, Diggle killing, grid based, rogue-like indie game from Gaslamp Games. Dungeons of Dredmor is a really simple and challenging game, when starting a new game you are first asked to choose between difficulties, permanent death or not and smaller dungeons with the same number of enemies and, if you have the DLC an additional 15 levels to go through. You will not be hurting for things to see and do in Dungeons of Dredmor also, if anyone has gotten 100% on it you are truly one of a kind. Next you are greeted with picking skills, you can choose up to 7 skills from a list of 50 different skills, all offering unique abilities and play styles, and once you've chosen between such skills as Emomancy, Killer Vegan and Bankster you choose male or female and enter the dungeons! The story behind this game is that the evil lich Dredmor was imprisoned beneath the world for being a meanie but, has slowly eroded away his bonds and you are asked to enter into his prison (or dungeon) and stop him!...again! Its dirt simple but, hey it works well and the dungeons are no joke. The game is grid based and combat is turned based, you can click or use the keyboard to move, upon entering combat you trade shots with your foe, (or take turns), the challenge of Dredmor is in how you build your character and, a little bit of luck with finding powerful items and shrines but, mostly in how you build your character. Although there are many skills to pick from some are better suited for dungeoneering than others, some only work better with other skills and there are some that are must haves, make no mistake there are ideal builds for this game. Items come in to play a little bit, especially food and healing items but, the crafting system in Dredmor is deep, there is a lot to craft and I haven't personally seen it but, what I have seen is almost every item in the game being craft-able. There are also skills associated with crafting, so you can build your character around any of the crafts if you so choose (such as being a clockwork, steam-punk knight) and, crafting things is as simple as having the crafting kit and using it with the correct items and there are a TON of items to craft. The graphics are also nice with this mix of hand painted/ comic look style, the game also runs as smooth as butter and, looks so simple you should be able to run it on just about anything so it's a great game for laptops. My only complaint about the graphics is more of a personal desire, the game shows you all these really neat hand-drawn items that look totally badass however, it never shows on your character; your character always will have the same frilly Guybrush Threepwood outfit regardless of the badass armor and traffic cone you have equipped, that kind of detail would have been greatly appreciated. Music in the game is excellent, with lots of organ, piano and strings, giving a sort of melancholy tune alongside some quirky upbeat tunes. The tracks tend to repeat if you linger on a floor too long so that may be a downside depending on how much you like it and, the music is what you'll listen to the majority of the games (in fact it often overpowers the other sounds of the game) so it’s a good thing it’s an awesome soundtrack.Dungeons of Dredmor is funny and challenging, a great game to play anywhere and caters to a lot of playstyles, it’s a solid experience and gives you a huge amount of content to enjoy for a cheap price of $4.99 USD. For $6.99 USD you can get the complete set which I honestly suggest because it’s a great deal for the amount of added content you get even if you don’t end up seeing all of it. If you want a challenge, or a never ending rogue-like game, enter the Dungeons of Dredmor!TL/DR; Dungeons of Dredmor is a rogue-like dungeon crawler with a HUGE amount of content for $4.99 USD, it’s got humor, charm and challenge, with plenty to do and replay ability to the Nth degree. It’s really cheap for what you get, Gaslamp Games certainly is giving you bang for your buck, honestly, if you don’t own the game, consider getting the full package for $6.99 USD, it’s just a few extra bucks and well worth it, plus the DLC by itself is $5.98 USD on its own so don’t waste your money unnecessarily! Check it out and support these guys so we can get more greatness in the future! -Double Thumbs up from RoyialVideo Reviews: youtube.com/RoyialNetwork

content:
Posted: February 21, 2012
												A game that is both a roguelike and hilarious. There are not many games like this. Packed with nerdy references galor and infinite replayability, it's hard to not adore this game. Tons of skills to choose from (even more if you get the $3 expansion), including skills such as Necronomiconomics, Psionics, Mathemagic, Golemancy, and Fungal Arts. There are tons of skills to choose from to make your ideal "hero". There are also a variety of difficulties/modes to play on, and since every floor of the dungeon is randomly generated, you'll always be surprised. This is one of the funnest indie games I have ever played, and I think it deserves more attention.The expansion, Realm of the Diggle Gods, introduced the skills Big Game Hunter, Emomancy, Werediggle, Killer Vegan, Piracy, and Demonologist, along with100 new items, 5 new dungeon levels, and many other little things. It also doubles the amount of genders you can choose for your character.

												I wasted 29 hours on this game until the corrupted savegame error hit me. That's when I completely lost interest in it. There's no fix for it. I do not want to work with a game where I constantly have to keep working around and muddle with save games in windows folders and backup copies. This is not the MS-DOS era. 												Unique and challenging at times, it's a joy to play. The humour and various references are great. There are numerous skills that you can mix and match to become whoever you. An axe weilding communist vampire? An archealogist dual sheild weilding vegan? The choices are endless and the mods from the Workshop can add countless more.I've only beaten the game twice but its still fun to try new combinations and see what works and what doesn't.  I usually come back to this game every few months spend hours playing it.  Its a unique game( at least for me, i had never played  a roguelike before) and i just enjoy the humour. For the price, you can't really go wrong.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Dungeons of Dredmor is an RPG set in a fantasy world. Play as a noble hero who must stop the demonic Lord Dredmora. The once very powerful, was finally defeated, stripped of his power, and then thrown into the underworld. Centuries later, after regenerating his powers, Lord Dredmor decides once again to destroy the human world. Before the start of the game create your avatar. Producer gave up from the traditional choice of character classes. Instead, we assign our hero seven skills that come along with the progress in the game, we can develop. Moving around randomly generated locations (mostly dungeons) kill hundreds of enemies, collect treasures and avoid traps. A variety of weapons includes swords, axes, and magic. During the game we are able to combine items and create them, such as healing potions or better weapons.8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Warning, if you've never played this game, minor spoilers ahead. (Like, really minor, but spoilers nonetheless.)This game is a unique combination of simple, easy, difficult, relaxing, laid-back, humorous, and just general old-fashioned fun. Holy crap it's fun. Basically you crawl your way through levels of the dungeon to get to the main bad-guy, accumulating a number of unique and silly items, skills, and badassery. Levelling up always feels good, and gaining a skill almost always has a noticeable affect on your combat.Fair warning, you will die a lot. And if you're like me and love pain, you'll play on perma-death (which is optional). On about my fifth character, I was really getting into the swing of things. I had tons of items. I had a pocket dimension I could go to to dump unwanted detritus that might be useful in the future, and I'd just made it through the second floor (still haven't seen the third; the floors are fairly big and ooze with content and monsters). I was fairly powerful at this point, at least for the floor I was on, and easily laid waste to waves of monsters with the help of my zombies and clouds of poison that I conjured. So, feeling like a badass, I hopped over to my pocket dimension to drop off some loot, when I noticed that from said dimension I could also leap to other dimensions! "Okay, cool," so I did. Plowed through one small dimension, no sweat. So I go to another, run into two monsters, kill myself with my own poison cloud. It was my fault for not paying attention, but alllll the hard work, the several hours I'd put into his skills, levels, items. Gone!At that point I said to myself, "Okay, this is probably the point where going back to the first dungeon just becomes a tedious grind, and I won't want to play anymore." Well tonight I felt like trying again, trying some new skills. Frankly, it's no less fun than when I played for the first time. The floors are all randomly generated, so it's never the same run between characters.My current character has kicks that literally explode into fire, tearing through enemies like nothing, and I'm only on the first floor.It's not just the content, it's the little quirks. You can tell the developers had a blast making this game. Everything shines with creativity and humour, and it's just a lovely little game gah I love it.10/10, recommended a thousand times yes. It's cheap, you should buy it with the expansions. Get ready to lose at least a few hours a day.
