Posted: July 26, 2014
												Dungeons of Dredmor is a great roguelike game in the spirit of the original games. Turn based, dungeon crawl with challenges of inventory management (though a bit easier now).The challenge starts at the very beginning with the selection of a skill set that has the proper synergy (ghads, I actually wrote that? No, I'm not a middle manager, why do you ask) - though do give random a try (there's a badge for it). Tossed into this mix is crafting (and encrusting), spell and ammunition management, and choices about which skills to level up when.The theme game is to be taken light heartedly, but the challenge of the game is right up there with Nethack and its brethren (and yet, it is still much more approachable than the roguelikes of old). You will find new and interesting ways to die (there's a badge for that too). The game is a worth it at twice its standard price

Posted: February 18, 2014
												DoD is stupidly addictive and clearly made by people who love the roguelike-turnbased-dungeoncrawler genre. Many of the enemies, items, and skills are genuinely weird, but if you read the descriptions they're often funny and clever too.Much of the replayability comes from the 35 different skillsets (51 with all DLC) of which you pick 7 each game. These range from your standard Sword & Archery specialties, to Piracy & Archaeology, to originals like "Fleshsmithing" and "Mathemagic". I'd recommend starting with standard weapon & shield skills along with Promethian Magic and Psionics. Leave the Necronomiconomics and Killer Vegan skills for a later challenge :)Oh and there's optional crafting (weapons, traps, potions, magic wands, etc) with pretty big loot tables too.My only criticisms: the randomized sidequests are somewhat indecipherable and lame (but hey, treasure), and there's no way the game could be played well with a gamepad due to inventory and hotkey management.If you're still not sold, hey, the game has at least 9 types of cheese and 13 kinds of fungus for your character to eat.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												This game is a real treat.  It's not only a well drawn dungeon crawl done in the old school style of Rogue and Nethack, but it's bursting at the seams with geek humor and benefits from modern advances in design and game philosophy without sacrificing any of the rushlessness and lack of mercy that is the hardcore pedigree of this genre.  Standard skill packages like Swords, Dual Wielding, and Alchemy find use alongside more unconventional schools like Veganism, Emomancy, and Viking Magic.  As a difficult yet slickly humorous adventure, this is a definate fit for anyone with a penchant for heroic vandilism looking for some randomly generated fun.

Posted: March 11, 2012
												This game will have you hooked for hours, and that's honestly no lie. The game doesn't take itself seriously, and it knows that, and plays off that the entire time which definitely makes for an enjoyable experience; the humor doesn't get old as it has so many jokes and references. The gameplay itself might not be what you expect from a Roguelike-- it's not as complicated. However that doesn't make a bad rogue-like by any means, as the core mechanics are certainly there: you're gonna die and die and DIE until the game feels bored with you... and then will kill you at the final boss anyways, because well hey, it's a Roguelike and that's just what they do. You'll be playing this game for hours, trying to figure out what is the best combination of skills for your liking, how the enemies work, and what items do what and how they even do that. It's jolly good fun, the expansion is entirely worth it... and this, on complete, is less than eight dollars. It's literally a steal.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Do you like D&D and related fantasy RPGs? Fond of Rogue and its hoard of -like successors? Easily amused by nerdy jokes in flavour text and tool tips or by pop culture references in the names of achievements? Want to pretend you're a game developer and name an expansion pack? Then Dungeons of Dredmor is the Roguelike for you!It's also a pretty good little time-wasting game in and of its own right, even if the things above don't apply. Even if you don't get the expansion packs, the base game will occupy plenty of your time, so long as you have a hankering for wandering dungeons, picking up loot and learning what potions do by the time honoured method of drinking them and hoping it wasn't horrible poison. DoD is a Roguelike, obviously, so anyone with a low tolerance for RNG-related failure or starting over for the 8th time this morning should either avoid it or only play on Elves Just Wanna Have Fun Difficulty with permadeath off. The pointy-eared wimps. Dredmor lacks a traditional Class system - your character has a set of Skill trees which you pick out of a pretty long list from the obvious (Shieldmaster) to the slightly more bizarre (Tourist). These make for some weird and wonderful synergies as you combine your Vampiric powers of sparkling with Necroeconomics. A large part of the fun comes from exploring these skill trees - what exactly does a Magical Lawyer Clockwork Knight with Burglary and Viking Wizardry end up like?Like any Rogeulike, DoD can suffer from repetitive grind, but there's enough different skills to mess around with that it stands up to some pretty heavy play without becoming wearing too quickly. And any game can get dull if you spend too much time with it. There are a few issues, like the way that magic/missile builds can be the only way to win (assuming you ever actually GET to Lord Dredmor himself) and the crafting system is... well, functional. When you get to higher crafting levels, the lack of filters or a basic search option in the crafting menu is a little irksome. And, of course, the RNG plays a big factor in what ingredients and which blueprints you get to play around with. But these are minor flaws that don't detract from  Dredmor's overall experience. And since it has Steam Workshop, you can get around some of these with mods.Fun, funny Rogue-like and arguably the one responsible for the recent run of Roguelikes with graphics or Roguelike-lites as some folks refer to them. Also, pretty darn cheap and comes with Trading Cards for those of us who like that kind of thing.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												This is a roguelike game designed as a send-up of the genre.  The jokes are hilarious, particularly if you've put as much time as I have into classic roguelikes such as Nethack or Angband, and the gameplay is quite good on its own.  As far as I've seen, it doesn't really have the puzzle-solving aspect of those games, it's purely tactical hacking.  The skill trees are amusing (of course) and fun to play around with.  One drawback to Dredmor is that a lot of the controls are mouse based and every action is animated, making gameplay much slower than in the roguelikes I've played before.  This can be worked around with game options, and I would recommend playing with the speed turned up (use "+" key) and autopickup enabled.If I have a few minutes to kill and am not in the mood for twitch zombie shooting, this will be at the top of my list.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Yesterday I picked up a copy of Dungeons of Dredmor by Gaslamp Games on Steam for a deliriously low price. I had previously seen the game-play trailer on the Steam store page but wasn't sure about picking up the title until I saw this video from The Cynical Brit. Who, by the way, is awesome, and not just because his English accent makes everything just slightly funnier.Dungeons of Dredmor is basically an old-school roguelike game, similar to Angband. It's got all of the typical roguelike features: it's really hard, you die a lot, there's random junk everywhere, there's tons of monsters, you die a lot, etc etc. What it adds to the genre is, wait for it... graphics! Don't get me wrong, roguelikes are great, I've had a lot of fun with Angband, but monochrome text characters gets a little tiring. Also, I have a mouse; it is not a new invention; it is wonderful for controlling things. Dredmor is capable of understanding the mystical signals that emanate from mice, it's amazing!What's especially great about the game is that it really doesn't take itself very seriously. Everything is silly and strange and ridiculous. For example, my character specializes in growing mushrooms. No, seriously, I grow mushrooms on the corpses of my slain enemies. And then I eat them (the mushrooms). You can get suits of armor made out of bright pink plastic. There's references to all sorts of pop-culture and even terribly obscure geek culture. Just before going to bed last night I found a "Horadric Lutefisk Cube". If you don't get the reference, then you are a poor and sad creature and I pity you.Of course if you don't like roguelikes, you probably won't like this game very much. It's about as old-school as you can get and still be a new game though. Luckily, they've also implemented 3 difficulty settings, and the ability to disable permadeath, for, you know, giant♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Which does make the game a lot more approachable.But where else can you throw baseballs at demons that do lightning damage?

Posted: January 24, 2014
												If you have a thing for classic dungeon crawlers, and consider yourself a fan of the Rogue-likes genre, then DoD is worth the money hands down. It makes up for what it lacks in graphics with an abundance of classes, skills, items, and genuinely clever content written about all the above. The ability to play with perma-death keeps me going, and for those that would rather a more casual game, you can simply turn it off.  Throw in randomly generated dungeons, and now you have a great game worth holding onto.The first few plays through you may well end up dying horribly from the unsuspecting trap or challenging enemy, but once you get a feel for which classes work well together it really just comes down to patience, skill and a just the right amount of luck as any good rogue-like does. If you're having trouble progressing far in the dungeon, its probably due to a bad build or unwillingness to try something new. Overall its a great RPG with a unique class system, interesting crafting, tons of DLC and player made content, and a good sense of humor.

												As roguelikes go, this one's definitely very approachable. It's got a great sense of humor, and a nice amount of depth to it that doesn't overwhelm you. When I'm in the mood for something that doesn't require twitch reflexes and allows me to plan things out at a casual pace, I load this up. There IS a slight learning curve to it though, so the first death or two (because yes, you will frequently die since this IS a roguelike) will leave you scratching your head... and while the tutorial will give you an idea on how the controls work it doesn't really give you any ideas on exactly HOW you should be playing.If you're even vaguely curious about the roguelike RPG genre, give this one a try.

Posted: December 30, 2011
												I watched the trailer and I was like, "Meh." I played the tutorial and I was like, "Meh." Then I tried actually playing through some games, and it turns out this game is surprisingly addictive.In particular, the skill trees are actually a lot of fun. You pick a set of skills when you start out, and you get to gradually advance them, which is very satisfying. And depending on the skills you choose, the game plays significantly differently, which is some serious replay value. Seriously. So much replay value. It's insane.There's a lot of visceral pleasure in exploring the dungeons, uncovering new rooms, beating the monsters senseless, and stealing all the treasure. It's much more fun than I thought it would be.

Posted: July 14, 2012
												Now, for those that grew up on rogue games, this one is much more timid. However, it has graphics :).  The sense of humor makes me chuckle, and the game play, other than crafting, is very tight.I really like all the many combinations of unique builds you can make based around a list of characteristics rather than just one class.  It keeps the game interesting even after a few deaths. And you will die.  Permadeath is really the only way to play this, as it adds that extra tension that makes the thing so exciting in the first play.  Not much for story, but as a turned based dungeon craller, you won't find much better than Dredmor.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												I own a lot of games, but this is the one that I keep coming back to most often. The game is clever and funny, riffing on practically every major fantasy or sci-fi movie book or game of the past century (Dwarf Fortress, Doom, Quake, Half-Life, Elder Scrolls, Conan the Barbarian, the Cthulhu Mythos, Planet of the Apes, Harry Potter, The Wicker Man, Star Trek, Dungeons & Dragons, Diablo, Pac-Man, Warhammer, Super Mario, The Thing, The Blob, Master of Magic, the list goes on and on; There's a seventeen page long list on the developer's forum and it's still imcomplete), yet it also has more than enough depth to still remain interesting long after you've seen all of the jokes. (And if you -do- get bored with what is included in the game, one of the official expansions is free and several of the fan-made mods {specifically FAXPAX, Interior Dredmorating, Compleat Essential Skills, Roguish Renovation, ASCII Invasion, and Swashbuckling} are of a quality comparable to the core game).One word of warning however: The game does not interact correctly with the steam's SteamCloud remote savegame system and the developers have so far been unable to figure out why, so it is recommended that you turn SteamCloud off for this game if you don't want your save files randomly erased. Erasure of save files may also occur if the game crashes while autosaving.

												I purchased this game along with a handful of other rogue-like games during a bundle and I was not expecting much. This game not only blew my expectations out of the water but it took the whole ocean with it! The game has a massive class system where you can mix and match more then a dozen classes together to create something truly fun and fullfilling. Want to make a dual wielding axe berserker who only eats his veggies and has a soft spot for animals? Done! Want to make a Vampire mage who sold his soul to the undead to attain Necro magic? Done! I could go on theres so much replay value this game has its insane. Theres also a crafting system aswell as you go deeper into the dungeon you pick up reagents used to make armor,weapons,potions,bombs,traps, the list goes on! I could type out a wall of text on how great this game but you have to experience it for yourself. Bottom line for 5 bucks this game is worth it and I would have gladly pay more b/c the developers deserve it!

Posted: May 24, 2014
												Dungeons of Dredmor is the first "indie" game that I remember completely and utterly loving.  For the first month that I owned it, I spent pretty much every night until 3-4AM slowly progressing through the eponymous dungeons, listening to Rush's Caress of Steel on loop (great combination, by the way).  Dredmor displays an impressive and very intelligent combination of depth and accessibility, offering a fun early game to hook you in, followed by challenging middle- and end-games to keep you coming back for just one more try.  Additionally, the game costs $5 at full price, which seems almost ridiculous when compared to the trend of steadily increasing prices for indie games of generally lower quality.  If I have one complaint about the game, it is probably that (to me, at least) weapon-based character builds seem to be much harder to use than magic based builds (especially those involving Promethean magic), though this is likely due to ignorance on my part, as I'm sure there are people out there who dominate with fighter/rogue/shooty-man builds.  However, none of this is to say that I do not have fun seeing how far I can get as a fighter-type, because I do.  9.5/10

												Surprisingly clever and fun game.  Highly recommended. Posted: July 2, 2014
												This game is great. For those of you that love the hack and slash, mob slaughtering, loot grabbing, pun filled dungeon crawl with tons of class customization and tweaking, this game is for you. Don't let the low amount of time Steam says I've spent on this game fool you. I spent quite a bit on it at a friends house trying it out. This game is quick to suck you in, although it's easy enough to save your progress if need be and pick it back up later. There is a bit of a learning curve when it comes to figuring out which combinations of character skills you need to actualy survive based on your play style, but with three different modes to play on, one of which being a permadeath mode, you can learn as you go. A couple of other great things I like about this game, is you can actually choose to be a female adventurer, which to me is great, as most dungeon crawlers try to put the female character as a spell slinger or an archer. I'm a girl, I prefer to be hacking off limbs in the front lines. This game lets me do just that. Replay values in this game are insane as well, since you never know what your dungeon is going to look like. Each one is randomly generated, with mobs, side quests, loot... This is just amazing to me. Heck, you can even get mods and install mods and extra content for this game that other people have created. Controls are fairly simple, and you can adjust your keybindings if need be as with most games of this genre. All in all, this game is well worth the cost, and getting it on sale is definitely a must. I recommend this game to anyone with a few bucks to spend on a game. You won't be disappointed.

 Great, fun, and funny. A Baby's first Roguelike One of the easier classic Roguelikes.The game itself is like an introduction to traditional/classic Roguelikes.Notable Features/Pros are:   Turn-based combat and gameplay akin to traditional roguelike mechanics  A humorous, albeit too much, approach to conquering a dungeon.  A good number of specs/classes to combine and choose from.  Near infinite replayablity due to modding.  A light enchantment system and a large number of weapons and armor to go along with it.  RNG is very fair compared to RLs such as Angband/Nethack Rating 7/10   A roguelike that is definitely on the easier side of the RL Difficulty spectrum. Definitely recommended as it is fun, quirky and fairly cheap and for those looking for a starting place on Roguelikes. Also a great addition to your steam RL collection.

Posted: November 4, 2015
												The funny thing about this game is this:The major cons that I would cite are not the fault of the developers. It's things along the lines of the fact that there is no readily accessible wiki that is up to date. It takes some major diggling around to find the one that actually includes proper enemy stats or all of the encrusting recipes. And yes, I understand that a lot of people want to discover things for themselves, but you'll be kicking yourself the first time you discover that yes, you DID need to keep all of those steaks for Gaga's Glaze, or that bronze is very useful for the Offensive Shielding encrust.The other thing that I would note is that you can hit endgame gear  pretty quickly (about dungeon level 5-7 out of 15), so there can be a very odd difficulty curve where you no longer have any significant changes to your stats, but things will get pretty tough. If I were to change anything, it would be to make that curve a bit more linear.Otherwise this game is fantastic. For a price tag of $5, I have played this far more than many other titles in the genre.

Posted: August 1, 2012
												A turn based rogue-like dungeon crawler with great humour and is very unforgiving. This game is best played on the hardest difficulty and permadeath enabled. I would recommend that you buy the expansions to unlock more skills to play around with. This game also has a modding community with the Steam Workshop so you could spend countless hours messing around with different builds. However your goal in this game is to murder Lord Dredmor, who's in either room 10 or 15, depending on your settings. If you're not a fan of grinding I would definitely recommend you enable "No time to grind" which makes each floor smaller but you still get the same amount of experience from clearing them. The only weakness for that option is you won't get as much item drops so your equipment could be poor and you won't get as much crafting items for crafting skills.You may reach the stage where nothing can stand in your way but don't let that fool you. Room 15 will kick your♥♥♥♥♥if you aren't prepared.

Posted: July 5, 2015
												This is a roguelike game, but it doesn't have the bizarre interface, hard-to-learn game mechanics, or ascii-graphics normally associated with the genre, making it very accessible and an excellent introduction to roguelikes.  Some of the jokes appear to be aimed at veterans, though.  There are a lot of jokes and a very strange sense of humour.  This doesn't mean it's a silly game - the game itself is not a joke, but a lot of the flavour text is. Instead of choosing a class, you choose 7 skills, ranging from weapon skills, armour skills, numerous magic skills, dodging, veganism, geology, archaeology...  so although there's no "warrior" class, you can just make a warrior by choosing all weapon and armor skills.  Or make a mage, or a rogue, or just about anything in between.  Because of the way heavy armor and spellcasting work together (they don't), warrior-wizard hybrids have some problems, but any other hybrid can work well.There are also crafting skills, and a lot of craftable items and discoverable recipies.  Thanks to some very powerful craftables introduced in the expansion packs, crafting is a bit overpowered.Modding support is very good - indeed, the free expansion pack is mostly made up of of the best player-made mods.I have very few complaints.  One is that the final boss is *MUCH* more dangerous than anything that comes before it.  The problem is not the toughness of the boss by itself, it's just that the rest of the game doesn't do a good job of teaching the player how to deal with him.Also, this is an indie game, made with an indie budget.  Occasionally that shows, like with late-game monsters that look like palette-swapped versions of earlier monsters.  It also comes with an indie price tag, and that makes it excellent value for money.

Posted: October 19, 2015
												The only turn-based roguelike I will ever need. I could play this game endlessly, and for any amount of time. Sometimes for just a few minutes, wandering into one or two more rooms, sometimes for hours at a stretch. The skills are numerous and varied and the crafting system is excellent. There are a lot of character stats, but you don't need to know all of them to start playing. Most things have tooltips, so you'll learn as you go. Personally, I think the game should be played with permadeath on. That way you can try different builds, searching for the one that will net you the least embarrassing death when you ultimately fail.

Posted: August 1, 2015
												1st delve.-Killed first by a diglet of Diggles (plural(or it should be in my opinion))-Rage Quit for being killed in the first room.2nd delve-Created the ultimate warrior wielding sword, axe and viking magic.-Killed by a Blob who claimed no one loved him, I can't imagine why cause he attack me on sight.-Rage quit because a blob got too excited and hugged me too roughly, snapping my spine.Loved every second of the rage and fell in love with this game.In all seriousness, despite my relatively short play time (Just over an hour). I can definetly see the appeal of this game, although somewhat "lack luster" in it's hand drawn art style (which i personally find very endearing but some may not). the game is a turn based, tile by tile "rogue like", rpg, dungeon crawler. With a few refrences to boot - I have a trait called "Witcher" and i quote "Going by the name "White eyebrows" you travel the world killing monsters for good, and making witty and sarcastic comments about various social endeavors -, the game unlike most rogue liek rpgs does not by any means take itself seriously, humour riddles the sprawling floors of the dungeons, with the various enemies insulting you and making genric comments about various aspects of you, the dungeons facilities (Quote - "The vodka is good, but the steak is stale" ).But like most games in the rogue liek genre, it turns into a loot rush as you scurry to gather gear all the while avoiding what would be considered tier 1 mobs and very easy fights due to the sheer squishiness that you character can suffer if the right traits aren't picked.All in all... "The vodka's good, but the steak is stale". The game is characterful, but the genres it's in is bloated and stale dragging this gem down with it.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												On a personal level, Dredmor hit a sweet spot of nostalgia, complexity, and charm that really resonated with me. The game's lighthearted nature helps keep it casual, but the depth of options and decisions to be made make it challenging and rewarding. It's a classic-style roguelike: tile+turn based, combat heavy, randomly generated dungeons, and a good variety of weapons, armor, and skills to equip yourself with.From the art-style to the item descriptions, to the tool tips for environmental curiosities, I was consistently (and pleasantly) surprised by the attention to detail. Even the modding community does an excellent job of keeping with the spirit of the game's charm, and many of the mods out there are so seamlessly integrated artistically that it feels like the game could have shipped with them. When I picked this title up on a steam sale years ago, I was not expecting to get so much value for such a small investment.

Posted: April 20, 2015
												Dungeons of dredmor allows you to make a version of iron man.As in, Mr tony stark..If you get pretty damn good.-Unarmed-Tinkering-Blacksmith-Clockwork Knight-Perception(Optional, But useful)-Master of Arms/Shield Skill-Etc.(Note:This setup does require the full DLC set, But its worth a look)Roguelikes are at once brutal, Entertaining, And very often a timesink once you work out the patterns.They are the games where you quite casually toss characters into a meat grinder to see what comes out.Roguelikes are glorious, And this, While easier than the usual genre fare..Is a good option.You begin by selecting a hero/heroine with no random name selector, Forcing some creative juices to flow.The next screen is somewhat more imposing, Especially the first time.Seven skill groups are picked that define what your character can do in the game context, And then you are let loose with a short blurb that basically says the hero meant to head down was on his lunchbreak, So you go down instead.The above build i mentioned is based around a style of play, Namely that of the sturdy and/or drunken warrior.It is very possible to be a sneaky fellow lobbing crossbow bolts, A drunken mad scientist with helper fungus..Or a vegan emo-pirate, Because why not.The drops are random, Creatures silly and endearing, and victory is never a sure thing.If worth nothing else, The game is good for a brief look to dip your toes into the roguelike genre.Skol!

Posted: July 16, 2012
												This is a roguelike for people who normally don't care for them. It's very fair and tactical, so rather than being screwed by the random number generator, deaths are usually well and truly your own damn fault. It also has longevity: the variety of skills and steam workshop integration ensure you'll always have a new way to play the game. Lastly, the writers have a very silly and enjoyable sense of humor, which helps give the game a quirky flavor quite unlike anything else out there.

Posted: July 12, 2012
												Dungeons of Dredmor is something you get when you take an appropriately brutal Rouge-like game and mix it with not only the offbeat comedy of an RPG a la Earthbound but with geeky shout-outs strewn into a pile on the murky floor. It'll take you roughly 20 hours to finish the game since you'll need a LOT of experience in order to take on the final boss whom is mixed amongst his followers on the final floor of the dungeon (so you can either find him right away or be forced to search every room, in either case it doesn't end well). You'll need to grind to survive, especially on later floors. Thankfully there's an option for those who don't live on level grinding like myself so I can recommend this game to just about anyone who likes a good RPG. In other words, expect to die a lot but not enough to make the game unfun.If I were to sum up Dungeons of Dredmor to an emotion, it would be that of finding a Monster Zoo in this game: complete surprise followed by fearing for your life.

Posted: November 4, 2015
												The funny thing about this game is this:The major cons that I would cite are not the fault of the developers. It's things along the lines of the fact that there is no readily accessible wiki that is up to date. It takes some major diggling around to find the one that actually includes proper enemy stats or all of the encrusting recipes. And yes, I understand that a lot of people want to discover things for themselves, but you'll be kicking yourself the first time you discover that yes, you DID need to keep all of those steaks for Gaga's Glaze, or that bronze is very useful for the Offensive Shielding encrust.The other thing that I would note is that you can hit endgame gear  pretty quickly (about dungeon level 5-7 out of 15), so there can be a very odd difficulty curve where you no longer have any significant changes to your stats, but things will get pretty tough. If I were to change anything, it would be to make that curve a bit more linear.Otherwise this game is fantastic. For a price tag of $5, I have played this far more than many other titles in the genre.

Posted: July 23, 2011
												For the low low price of 5 dollars, this game is difficult (as a roguelike should be), but is packed with hilarious enemies, amusing item descriptions, and exudes a sense of self-parody that is well integrated without becoming grating. There are too many instances that I have laughed out loud while playing, but the funniest is probably the screen in which you die. "CONGRATULATIONS! YOU DIED!" it says triumphantly. This game is well worth the 5 dollars you shell out for it, and then some. I can't wait to see what the subsequent updates will add to this already excellent gem of a game.

												Really fun rogue dungeon crawler with a lot of depth and moddability. It took me 40 hours to beat the game once. Posted: December 29, 2011
												Dungeons of Dredmor was certainly a nice surprise for me. I was expecting an "easy" Rougelike with a pretty interface, and while this is true to some extent, this game has got some charm of its own. The difficulty is lowish if you're used to NetHack, Angband and the like, but if you aren't, it can be a devilishly hard game, so expect to die- often. And masochistically ask for more. There are lots of gags and pop culture references thrown around in the game, just check the names of the achievements and the lines creatures utter before attempting to kill you. The game is rough around the edges, and there are a few control issues here and there, but for the most part, nothing that would seriously affect your gameplay. All in all, I recommend it.

Posted: May 3, 2015
												This game is addicting! You choose what abilities you start with, some of which are normal fantasy tropes, but then quickly move into silliness (e.g. vegan powers?!). Part of the charm of this game is that you have to figure out what combination of abilities/powers work. Then you head out armed with an orange plastic street cone on your head and a cardboard sword. The game mocks you when you die, which can happen pretty frequently. You do have the ability to turn off perma-death if that's your thing. The DLC just makes the game more fun. The mods also add all sorts of fun new things. There is a lot of crafting, if you take the abilities to advance in it, and you can make some pretty zanny stuff, which tends to be more powerful than the standard gear you come across.This is an extremely addicting turn-based game, and I can't recommend it enough. A++

Posted: April 1, 2012
												Nethack/10.Losing is fun! And you'll be doing a lot of it. This is a pure roguelike, meaning you'll be crawling around dungeons, killing monsters, casting spells, and never being 100% sure if the next door you open will reveal a room full of hundreds of hungry monsters.DoD really does feel like a more graphical Nethack, with its own charm and sense of humor.You absolutely can't go wrong for the price, and it'll run on almost anything. The graphics and audio, while low res (the music sounds very midi), are catchy and memorable.A great game, and highly recommended at almost any price.

Posted: August 1, 2015
												1st delve.-Killed first by a diglet of Diggles (plural(or it should be in my opinion))-Rage Quit for being killed in the first room.2nd delve-Created the ultimate warrior wielding sword, axe and viking magic.-Killed by a Blob who claimed no one loved him, I can't imagine why cause he attack me on sight.-Rage quit because a blob got too excited and hugged me too roughly, snapping my spine.Loved every second of the rage and fell in love with this game.In all seriousness, despite my relatively short play time (Just over an hour). I can definetly see the appeal of this game, although somewhat "lack luster" in it's hand drawn art style (which i personally find very endearing but some may not). the game is a turn based, tile by tile "rogue like", rpg, dungeon crawler. With a few refrences to boot - I have a trait called "Witcher" and i quote "Going by the name "White eyebrows" you travel the world killing monsters for good, and making witty and sarcastic comments about various social endeavors -, the game unlike most rogue liek rpgs does not by any means take itself seriously, humour riddles the sprawling floors of the dungeons, with the various enemies insulting you and making genric comments about various aspects of you, the dungeons facilities (Quote - "The vodka is good, but the steak is stale" ).But like most games in the rogue liek genre, it turns into a loot rush as you scurry to gather gear all the while avoiding what would be considered tier 1 mobs and very easy fights due to the sheer squishiness that you character can suffer if the right traits aren't picked.All in all... "The vodka's good, but the steak is stale". The game is characterful, but the genres it's in is bloated and stale dragging this gem down with it.

Posted: August 3, 2015
 Great, fun, and funny. A Baby's first Roguelike One of the easier classic Roguelikes.The game itself is like an introduction to traditional/classic Roguelikes.Notable Features/Pros are:   Turn-based combat and gameplay akin to traditional roguelike mechanics  A humorous, albeit too much, approach to conquering a dungeon.  A good number of specs/classes to combine and choose from.  Near infinite replayablity due to modding.  A light enchantment system and a large number of weapons and armor to go along with it.  RNG is very fair compared to RLs such as Angband/Nethack Rating 7/10   A roguelike that is definitely on the easier side of the RL Difficulty spectrum. Definitely recommended as it is fun, quirky and fairly cheap and for those looking for a starting place on Roguelikes. Also a great addition to your steam RL collection.

Posted: August 11, 2015
												A fun roguelike with a tongue-in-cheek kinda humor, nice visuals and a good, if repetitive soundtrack. The combat system is skilltree and cooldown based, which keeps trying out different combinations interesting - although many combinations will prove useless in the endgame, especially when trying to tackle the final boss. But that's kinda the point of trying out different builds - where's the fun in alt-tabbing to a guide every other round? All things considered it is a good way for roguelike beginners to make their baby steps in the genre.  Experienced RL players might get bored after several runs, though.

												A fantastic entry level roguelike - if you've ever been interested in the genre, but games like Stone Soup are too intimidating then this is for you.The humor may be quite hit or miss - but anyone who has played a lot of tabletop or board games may get a few chuckles here and there. Posted: February 18, 2014
												DoD is stupidly addictive and clearly made by people who love the roguelike-turnbased-dungeoncrawler genre. Many of the enemies, items, and skills are genuinely weird, but if you read the descriptions they're often funny and clever too.Much of the replayability comes from the 35 different skillsets (51 with all DLC) of which you pick 7 each game. These range from your standard Sword & Archery specialties, to Piracy & Archaeology, to originals like "Fleshsmithing" and "Mathemagic". I'd recommend starting with standard weapon & shield skills along with Promethian Magic and Psionics. Leave the Necronomiconomics and Killer Vegan skills for a later challenge :)Oh and there's optional crafting (weapons, traps, potions, magic wands, etc) with pretty big loot tables too.My only criticisms: the randomized sidequests are somewhat indecipherable and lame (but hey, treasure), and there's no way the game could be played well with a gamepad due to inventory and hotkey management.If you're still not sold, hey, the game has at least 9 types of cheese and 13 kinds of fungus for your character to eat.

												This Rogue-like game, that is a turn-based gameplay, with an interesting Perma-death mechanic.While there are more games since this one has come out, the game has done things ell enough things right, that it still worth playing and even the new games haven't been able to take away from this game.Steam Workshop support that allows for a whole host of customizations with community driven changes/additions is welcomed and likely has given this game the live it has seen.KB&M work wonders, graphics are solid, stable game & just interesting overall.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Dungeons of Dredmor, where do I begin? One of the original indie rogue-like darlings in my memory. A truly fantastic rogue-like with a great sense of humor, exploration and music to boot. This game is all about exploring randomly generated dungeons floor by floor until you reach the deepest level and defeat the big bad guy. That being said, it is no small feat doing so and will take quite a long time.The game starts out by allowing you to choose a number of skills trees to associate with your newly created character from Mastery of Fungi to Viking Magic and everything in between. The first skill from each tree is automatically granted to you at the start of the game. Each time you level up you gain one skill point which can be placed in any skill tree you desire. This system of mixing and matching what skill trees are available to your character allows for a great deal of customization and replay value.Each floor in the Dungeon of Dredmor is increasingly difficult and will require you to raise your level as well as seek out better equipment for your character. There are an incredible amount of items, weapons and armors for you to discover and that number is made even larger by secret recipes you discover along the way. Crafting is another large part of the game as many of the items you pick up are only useful for crafting other items. For example you come across many different type of ingots which are used to smelt armor and weapons both mundane and special. Without crafting these items simply take up space in your inventory so it is important to learn the usage of many items in recipes.  There are monster galore in the dungeon and simply clicking on an adjacent creature will attack it. Enemies can dodge, block and even counter your attacks and the same goes for you. It's all in the stats and this game has many, possibly too many? Many more stats than I can go into here, but with such a wealth of useful ones there are plenty of ways to build a functional character.The humor is spot on and I have found myself laughing at a number of things in the game from achievements to items and beyond. Enemies also like to give witty quips as you attack them and subsequently as they die. Musically Dungeons of Dredmor nails the MIDI sound and I can't say that's an easy thing to do. Usually I find MIDI sound to be quite limiting but not in this game. Almost all of the songs are very catchy and fit the mood one way or another. The soundtrack alone is worth checking out.Dungeons of Dredmor gets 9 Lutefisk out of 10

Posted: June 1, 2015
												What a great roguelike! DUNGEONS OD DREDMOR was the first commercial traditional roguelike that got popular, before-hand roguelikes were mostly free and way too complex for a broad audience. Dredmor came and changed that. Don't give me wrong; DoD still is a traditional roguelike but alot of the mechanics were dumbed down so that most of the people would understand them. DoD simplified a lot of stuff but kept the standard mechanics of a turn-based roguelike. This game still has the most important things:<> randomization  <> Perma Death (there also is an option to turn that off, again trying to appeal to a broad audience)<> Crafting<> Skill Trees<> QuestsDoD had all that but as I said simplified! And that's what makes this roguelike so great! It's simple yet so challenging and complex. It always keeps this fine balance between "dumb-easy" and "complex-easy". But this game is not easy to beat; not at all! DUNGEONS OF DREDMOR is pure roguelike-awesomeness, and it also is the perfect game to start for newcomers to the traditional roguelike genre.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												Yup, I've played this a lot so high marks for re-playability.I like the challenge of the game.  My efforts through most of the time spent plodding through the dungeons are mostly in an attempt to finish the game on the hardest level with a character using random skills.The skills are one of the best parts.  The number of them makes for some great synergisistic strategy development.  The humour is nice too, where else can you play a comunist banker vampire vegan with an ax?One problem is length.  In the full size mode it takes ages to clear each level but in the 'no time to grind' mode there is only a very limited amount of loot which can make some builds tough to play.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												I really like games that have a good mix of lightheartedness and difficulty, and this game brings just that. The randomness aspect of pretty much everything makes every run almost entirely different (unless you decide to use the same skill set every time which I don't recommend unless its the only one you are good at and oyu are going for a win). The ability to make a run short with the 'No Time to Grind' option is really nice, since   you can have quick runs in a game that usually takes a few hours for a near complete run(with DLC). I didn't play very much of the game before I got the DLC, but I can say that the DLC gave it what it might have needed: more stuff. The only problem (and it isn't a real problem) is that in the later floors there are mainly reskinned enemies. Many of them do different things than the original though, and there are still new enemies occasionaly, so this isn't something that takes away interest in the later floors.Essentially, this game has enough variety to allow most players to enjoy it and gives a lot of replay value like good roug-likes should do, but has plenty of comedy and difficulty to make it fun to play each time instead of just being different.

Posted: April 1, 2012
												Nethack/10.Losing is fun! And you'll be doing a lot of it. This is a pure roguelike, meaning you'll be crawling around dungeons, killing monsters, casting spells, and never being 100% sure if the next door you open will reveal a room full of hundreds of hungry monsters.DoD really does feel like a more graphical Nethack, with its own charm and sense of humor.You absolutely can't go wrong for the price, and it'll run on almost anything. The graphics and audio, while low res (the music sounds very midi), are catchy and memorable.A great game, and highly recommended at almost any price.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												If you're a fan of traditional roguelikes, you're a bit like a fan of hitting yourself in the knee repeatedly with the pointy end of a claw hammer. Dredmor puts a fun, inviting spin on what is essentially a vicious cycle of internal self-abuse. Losing a game repeatedly due primarily to random chance, but being tricked into thinking it's due to your poor optimization or lack of skill has never been so pleasant! Dungeons of Dredmor, the game that puts a lovable, cheeky attitude to your enternal torment!If you love roguelikes, you have my condolences. Maybe one day I'll start a support group.Hello, my name is Kaypar, and I am a roguelike player.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												A fantastic roguelike (yes, an actual turn-based roguelike), with a great sense of humor. In DoD, you'll fight everything from zombies to giant vegetables, while using equipment that references everything from Mario to Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy. There's a huge number of different weapons and armor to find, and plenty of different skills to choose between, from vampirism to burglary to becoming a vegan, and a crafting system to let you create and upgrade all kinds of new equipment. Also, you can kill the shopkeeper and take his stuff, so there's that.8/10 Terrified of Monster Zoos

Posted: September 9, 2014
												This is hands-down my favorite rogue-like (an actual rogue-like) that I've ever played. The base game itself contains so many ridiculous skill trees and items that its hard not to derive even a little fun from it even for those not into turn based RPG's. On top of that the DLC's add even more content that adds to the absurdity and wonder of this game and one of them is free. Also, this game is cheap as hell. It is easily worth triple what they are charging for it and I honestly feel kinda bad that I can't hand them more money. In addition, just in case you manage to somehow-inconceivabley-run out of things to do in the base game and DLC, the mod support for this game is fantastic, with hundreds of new skills, items, and enemies to be easily downloaded from the workshop. This game easily falls onto my list of must own games on Steam and for this price ($5) there is no reason not to own this game.
